III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Some reports indicate staff did not look for Youth A, but other
reports say staff did try to follow Youth A outside. It is unknown
how long Youth A was gone for, before staff notified Complainant,
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 4/21/2025. She
reported receiving the information about Youth A going AWOL
from Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3. She also reported the only other
information about the AWOL is that Youth A left around 6:30pm on
4/18/25 and took a cardboard box with him.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported being aware of the AWOL with Youth A
and believed the staff followed the AWOL policy. This involves
staff following a youth until they leave campus and making reports
to Law Enforcement, referring sources, parents, and licensing. He
also provided which staff (Staff 1, Staff 2, Supervisor 1, Therapist
1, and Supervisor 2) had any interaction in the event or knew of
the event.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported working 2nd shift on 4/18/25 (day of Youth
A going AWOL) and being informed of Youth A going AWOL by
both Staff 1 and Staff 2. He also reported receiving no details
about the AWOL but being asked by Staff 1 and Staff 2 to contact
the facility administration and licensing to inform them both of the
AWOL as required by policy. He also reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
followed the procedure for a youth going AWOL.
Therapist 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported not being present when Youth A went
2

AWOL and only finding out about the AWOL after the fact. He also
reported being Youth A’s therapist after Youth A’s behaviors
caused a need for a change in therapists. Therapist 1 was Youth
A’s primary therapist for a few months before Youth A was
changed to a third therapist because of staffing changes.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. Youth A reported going AWOL because he was tired
of the treatment and wanted a “better life”. Youth A also reported
not making any progress with his treatment and not liking the rule
of “not being allowed to masturbate in the bathroom”. Youth A
reported wanting to be his own person and having the courts drop
all charges against him. He also reported while on the run, Youth
A had everything he needed to survive such as food, shelter,
peace, and quiet with no help from anyone else. Youth A reported
staff don’t respect Youth A’s religion which Youth A described as
“Japanese” and “Shinto”. Youth A also reported his soul was born
in Japan and he is mentally Japanese not American. Youth A
reported walking out of the unit quickly when he went AWOL.
Youth A also reported being followed by Staff 2 until Youth A left
the property.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported working on the unit Youth A was lodged in
when Youth A went AWOL. He also reported, prior to leaving,
Youth A finished a chore after dinner, went into Youth A’s room
and came out carrying a box. Youth A walked to the door and left
the unit. Staff 1 reported staff are not allowed to stop youth from
leaving and staff are not allowed to follow youth off grounds. Staff
1 reported Youth A left so quickly, Staff 1 didn’t have time to
speak with Youth A before Youth A was out the door. He also
reported Staff 2 talked to Therapist 2 about the AWOL and Staff 1
spoke with Supervisor 1 about the AWOL. He reported being the
advocate for Youth A but once Youth A became negative towards
Staff 1 the change of the advocate was made. Staff 1 believes the
negative attitude was started by another peer (unable to identify
youth’s name but youth is gone from facility) who filled Youth A’s
head with negative thoughts about Staff 1 and the program.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/25/2025. She
reported Youth A has been on her caseload for approximately 3-
weeks and has had 7-individual therapy sessions over that time.
She also reported providing more individual sessions for Youth A
than any other youth on her caseload. Therapist 2 reported the
change in therapists for Youth A was made because her skill level
provides a better match for the issues Youth A is presenting.
3

Youth A wants to finish all assignments at once without
processing what is being presented. She also reported being
made aware of the AWOL on 4/18/25 and believes staff followed
the required procedures in response to Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 4/25/2025. She reported
being Youth A’s current advocate because Youth A was not
getting along with Staff 1 and believed Staff 1 was not meeting
Youth A’s needs. She reported being notified of Youth A’s AWOL
and believes staff followed procedures as required.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/28/25. He reported
being present when Youth A went AWOL on 4/18/25 from the
West Unit. He also reported not observing anything suspicious
from Youth A prior to Youth A running out of the unit and leaving
through the dining room door. Staff 2 reported following Youth A
outside and through the parking lot. He also reported stopping
when he reached the end of the property and returning to the
building to contact Law Enforcement. He reported Staff 1
contacted the parents and Therapist 2. He also reported a belief
that himself and Staff 1 followed the procedures for Youth A going
AWOL.
Documents Reviewed:
Bethany Christian Services Incident Report – Runaway
4/18/25 @ 18:20 for Youth A. Staff 2 is documented as
submitting this report and Staff 1 is documented as being
involved. It is documented that Youth A went into his bedroom,
returning approximately 5 minutes late, running out of the room
carrying a small tub and going out of the dining room exit. Staff
(unidentified in the report) are documented as observing Youth A
walking down Grand Ave around 6:30 pm. It is also documented
Staff (unidentified in this report) “made proper calls for this
situation” and staff checked Youth A’s room finding Youth A had
left a note. Documentation in this report indicates staff contacted
and informed the following: Law Enforcement, Therapist 2, JJ
Worker, Parent, and Licensing Consultant all on the same day of
the incident. Further documentation indicates Youth A was
returned to the facility on 4/23/25 by Parent.
Letter written by Youth A without a date. This letter is signed by
Youth A and begins with Youth A stating he has run away. The
letter does not address anyone specifically and states, Youth A is
taking only his belongings and nothing that is owned by the
facility. Youth A states he wants to be a free man and get away
4

from “all the abuse and pain” in his life. Youth A also states his
love for his mother and that he will become a better man so he
can visit his mother in the future.
Bethany Chrisitan Services Residential Treatment Program
Policies & Procedures 005-Truancy/Runaway Procedure
dated 6/21/24. This document outlines staff’s response to a youth
going AWOL. It is stated if a youth does leave the building, staff
are to make every attempt to locate the youth on campus and
return that youth back to the unit. During normal business hours
staff are to notify Supervisor, Residential Therapist and Assistant
Unit Supervisor. After normal business hours staff are to contact
the on-call supervisor, on-call clinician, and shift supervisor. Once
the youth is off campus, staff are to notify Law Enforcement,
Licensing Consultant, parent/guardian, and Administration.
Video Review:
A review of the video dated 4/18/25 of the unit Youth A was living
on. The view was of the unit, Youth A’s bedroom and the door
leading outside. Staff 1 is sitting on the couch and Staff 2 is
standing near the kitchen area. Youth A is observed walking out of
the bathroom and going into Youth A’s bedroom. A few moments
later, Youth A comes out of Youth A’s room, running across the
unit and exiting the door from the unit to the outside at 6:26:58
pm. Youth A was carrying what appeared to be a plastic tub and
wearing a brown jacket. Staff 2 follows Youth A out the door
leading outside.
Still photo review: a still photo of Youth was reviewed. In this
photo Youth A is observed walking through the unit with a brown
coat on and carrying a blue tub. Because of Youth A’s foot
positions (wide stride) it appears Youth A may be moving quickly.
Walk-through:
A walk-through was completed at the facility. The facility is well
furnished and maintained. Youth A’s bedroom was also well
furnished, maintained and clean.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with evidence by interviews with
staff, youth, documents reviews and a video review. The staff
followed the procedures for dealing with youth going AWOL.
5

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in the aspect of ensuring that
staff can be identified in incident reports. In the AWOL incident
report staff are referenced but not specific enough to identify the
staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/18/20, Staff 1 previously acted as Youth A's advocate, but a
new advocate had to be assigned as Staff 1 has been verbally
abusive to Youth A, calling him names and belittling him.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 4/21/2025.
Complainant reported Youth A informed Complainant that Staff 1
was being verbally abusive towards Youth A and Youth A filed a
written complaint. Complainant wanted to know what action the
facility was taking. She also reported Staff 1 was Youth A’s
advocate but because of the verbal abuse, Staff 3 was given the
role as Youth A’s advocate. Complainant reported filing a verbal
complaint about Staff 1 but had no knowledge of the outcome of
this verbal complaint. She also reported having no further
information about any of the complaints.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported not being aware of the allegations of staff
calling Youth A names and belittling Youth A. He reported being
aware of a grievance filed by Youth A about name calling and will
provide a copy plus documentation that was taken. Administrator
was interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025.
He reported receiving no grievances from Youth A in regard to
Youth A’s religion or staff making fun of Youth A’s religion. He also
reported there was a meeting between Youth A, Parent, and the
JJ worker in which complaints were discussed. He also reported
6

being told by JJ worker that Youth A and Parent were not able to
provide any specific details and didn’t seem to have much to
discuss.
Therapist 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. He reported Youth A did not meet the requirements for
a diagnosis of autism and a psychological test suggested a
personality disorder of narcissus. He also reported Youth A will
become argumentative at times and challenging towards rules and
authority. Therapist reported Youth A never spoke about staff
belittling Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. Youth A reported staff never called him a “bad” name
but would tell Youth A that Youth A lies a lot and Youth A doesn’t
know how to listen. Youth A reported being told by staff that Youth
A thinks everyone else is wrong and will not accept authority.
Youth A reported staff didn’t call him a liar but would use the term
lying. Youth A was unable to provide any specific example of staff
talking to him inappropriately. Youth A was interviewed again
face-to-face at the facility on 5/8/2025. Youth A reported Staff 1
laughed about Youth A’s religion prior to Youth A going AWOL on
4/18/25. Youth A was unable to provide any specific details as to
the day, time, location, and possible witnesses. Youth A was
asked about the complaint of abuse and reported not knowing
when Youth A was abused or how Youth A was abused. Youth A
reported the facility is looking into Youth A’s complaints but are
not informing Youth A of their findings. Youth A reported Staff 1
told Youth B that Youth A is claiming a religion for attention but not
to tell anyone.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. Staff 1 reported never saying anything negative or
inappropriate to Youth A or any other youth. Staff 1 also denied
ever calling Youth A, a liar but instead would tell Youth A that
“Youth A was not telling the truth or it’s not true you’re lying”. Staff
1 reported never hearing any staff call a youth a negative name or
using a belittling word. Staff 1 denied telling Youth A that Youth A
used Youth A’s religion for attention. Staff 1 did report raising his
voice which lead to the coaching note.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/23/2025. She reported Youth A has filed several grievances
against Staff 1 and she has talked to both Youth A and Staff 1
about these grievances. She also reported Youth A has said
Youth A has been trying to get Staff 1 in trouble or fired and Youth
7

A’s version of the grievances is not accurate. She reported telling
Youth A that Youth A needs to believe what Youth A wants to
believe but Youth A still needs to follow the rules. She also
reported Youth A has informed her that Youth A doesn’t believe in
the program. She reported Staff 1 has not engaged in any
inappropriate behaviors or speech. She also reported a situation
that occurred when Staff 1 began to raise his voice in a shouting
match with Youth A but was unable to recall what the incident was
based on. Supervisor 2 reported having a “coaching” meeting with
Staff 1 which will be provided, and informing Staff 1 that raising his
voice with a youth again will result in his employment being
terminated. Supervisor 2 reported Staff 1 was not yelling but did
raise his voice with Youth A. She also reported it appeared both
were engaged in a power struggle but again, unable to identify
specific details.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/25/2025. She
reported not observing or hearing any staff use negative language
with Youth A but did acknowledge that Staff 1 will let himself get
into an argument with Youth A. She reported Staff 1 is working on
making positive changes and other staff and supervisors are
keeping an eye on Staff 1’s interactions.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 4/25/2025. She reported
never hearing Staff 1 nor any other staff use negative statements
towards Youth A nor any other youth, but sometimes youth do not
like to be held accountable.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/28/25. Regarding the
interactions between Staff 1 and Youth A, Staff 2 reported Staff 1
and Youth A would get into a power struggle when Youth A began
to raise his voice towards Staff 1. He also reported once this
occurs, Staff 1 would also raise his voice engaging in the power
struggle. Staff 2 reported since Staff 1 had the coaching from
Supervisor 2, Staff 1 has avoided power struggles with Youth A.
He also reported Staff 1 has not raised his voice or got into a
power struggle since then.
JJ Worker was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. She reported receiving no official grievances from Youth
A and having Youth A tell her about issues when they meet. She
reported about the meeting with Youth A and Parent last week
and having Youth A unable to report any specific details or new
information. She reported monthly visits with Youth A and meeting
with Youth A weekly for the past couple of weeks. She reported
conducting Family Team Meetings every 90 days. She reported
8

Youth A is not truthful when providing information, but she will still
follow up on issues reported by Youth A.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth B reported staff do not tease youth and treat the
youth with respect. Youth B also reported the staff are “great” and
very helpful for the youth. Youth B reported the other youth will
joke about religion but never staff and only when it is brought up
by a youth. Youth B also reported Staff 1 is one of the best staff
but Youth A struggles with Staff 1. Youth B reported Youth A gets
upset with Staff 1 and tries to taunt Staff 1 into arguments. Youth
B also reported all the youth with the exception of Youth A get
along with Staff 1. Youth B reported never being told by Staff 1
that Youth A uses Youth A’s religion for attention however, Youth
B believes Youth A seeks a lot of attention. Youth B also reported
Staff 1 has never talked to Youth B about Youth A being a bad
youth. Youth B reported the program is very helpful and Youth B
feels safe in the program.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth C reported observing no mistreatment by staff
nor teasing by staff towards Youth A and any other youth on the
unit. Youth C also reported the program is helping Youth C and
Youth C feels safe in the program.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth D reported staff will joke with youth but not in a
mean way. Youth D also reported Youth A will claim staff are
abusing Youth A, but Youth D believes Youth A is making this
claim up. Youth D reported Youth A generally starts issues with
staff, but staff generally ignore Youth A when Youth A is being
inappropriate verbally. Youth D reported the program is helping
Youth D make changes and Youth D feels safe in the program.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/8/2025. Youth E gave a similar report to Youth C’s report. Youth
E has not observed staff being inappropriate with youth, especially
Youth A and never observed staff teasing youth. Youth E believes
the program is helpful and feels safe in the program.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 5/9/2025. She reported
working with Staff 1 twice a week on the unit with Youth A and
never observing Staff 1 or other staff laughing at Youth A. She
also reported the other youth do not laugh at Youth A. Staff 4
reported never observing staff being inappropriate in their
treatment of Youth A.
9

Documents Reviewed:
Bethany Chrisitan Services Residential Treatment Program
Policies & Procedures 005-Grievance Procedure dated
7/11/24. This document outlines the procedure for formal
grievance process for residents, parents, guardians, and other
legal representatives of the residents. Youth are provided a copy
of the grievance policy within the first week of placement and
grievance forms with envelopes are in the main living area on
each unit. Grievance forms are always available for all youth. It is
document that if an issue is a matter requiring urgent attention the
Unit Supervisor or Lead Therapist should be contact immediately.
Youth can complete the top part of the grievance form and place
in the provided envelope before placing the envelope in the
mental grievance box on the unit. Parents/guardians, case
manager, and other fill out the pdf form located online and email
the form to the Unit Supervisor. It is documented the Residential
Director will review the grievance within ten days and provide a
response to the youth. If the response is not satisfactory the
appeal process can be requested. This results in the grievance
being submitted to the Vice President of Regional Operations. All
grievances are printed in triplicate with one being placed in the
youth’s permanent file.
Bethany Chrisitan Services Residential Treatment Program
Policies & Procedures Supervision dated 6/14/22. This
document outlines staff are to supervise adolescents
proportionate to the youth’s level of trust. It is also documented
this program is a “relationship-based program”.
Meeting Notes email from Supervisor 2 dated 3/27/25. This
email documents the meeting between Supervisor 1, Supervisor
2, and Staff 1 on 3/25/25 for a Performance Coaching session. It
is documented the primary focus of this meeting with the
interaction that occurred between Staff 1 and Youth A that started
on 3/14/25 and ended in a “loud verbal argument between Staff 1
and Youth A the following day (3/15/25). A review of the video
recording of the two incidents was conducted and processed. Staff
1 agreed to attend the next Sanctuary Full Training on 4/22-4/24
and the full CPI training in June. Supervisor 2 documents, she will
assign an online training session of Self-Awareness/De-escalation
that Staff 1 can complete right away. It is documented that if any
similar type of conflict arises in the future, the matter will be
addressed through the appropriate HR channels.
10

HR file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was hired on 7/24/24.
Staff 1 is current on all training with the exception of the training
required for the performance coaching. There was one
performance coaching form in his personnel file which
documented an incident of employee behavior violation and client
treatment/management occurring on 3/14/25 and 3/15/25. The
incident is documented as Staff 1 and Youth A engaging each
other with Youth A accusing Staff 1 of being disrespectful for
calling Youth A a liar and Staff 1 telling Youth A that Youth A
never takes responsibility. It is documented that this interaction
lasted approximately 15 minutes. It is documented that a
confrontation took place between Youth A and Staff 1 the
following day after Youth A became dysregulated over the
assignment given by Staff 1. This led to an argument (no
documentation of yelling occurring) between Staff 1 and Youth A
that required other staff to physically intervene by stepping
between Staff 1 and Youth A. It is documented that when the
supervisor was made aware of the incident, Staff 1 was sent home
for the rest of the day. The outcomes were documented as Staff 1
will participate in a facilitated conversation with Youth A, attend
virtual Sanctuary Training on 4/22-4/24, and attend the full CPI
training on 6/10-6/11. This document was signed by Staff 1 on
3/25/25.
Email from Supervisor 2 on 4/25. She reports Staff 1’s progress
on the issues Staff 1 is to be working on. Staff 1 has reported no
conversation with Youth A has taken place yet because Youth A is
not ready to listen to Staff 1 or Staff 1’s apologies. Supervisor 2
also reported speaking with Youth A who informed her Youth A is
ready to listen and Staff 1 has informed her he will try to speak to
Youth A. Supervisor 2 will facilitate the meeting. She reported
Staff 1 was unable to complete the 3-day Sanctuary Training
because of schooling but is available to complete when it is
offered again. She also reported Staff 1 was unable to complete
the online training because of schooling but informed Staff 1 that
he needed to complete this ASAP,
Email stream dated 4/30/25 between JJ Worker Therapist,
Family Coordinator, and Administrator. JJ Worker asked about
Youth A’s rights in regard to Youth A’s religion since Youth A is
documented as bring this issue up often. JJ Worker also
documents Youth A’s upsets are directly correlated with Youth A’s
court hearing. JJ Worker states Youth A is not actually following a
religion, and it appears Youth A is making up his own rules for
Youth A’s religion. JJ Worker indicates she will ask Youth A for
specific complaints during the meeting with Youth A and Parent.
11

Administrator reports wanting to respect Youth A’s religious choice
and that they should ask Youth A to contact the local Shintoism
location/leader in the community. Administrator also reports that
youth in the program are not allowed to make up their own religion
that engage in a practices that are harmful to self or others.
Administrator reports Youth A wants access to Japanese anime
characters that are typically have exaggerated sexual features
and Japanese hentai which is a pornographic cartoon. Both of
these items are not allowed in the program.
Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment Program
Grievances filed by Youth A from 12/23/24 to 4/12/25.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 12/23/24 from Youth A. Youth
A states staff got bacon grease on the cabinets in the

expects staff to pay for the pants since the grease would
not come out. Youth A also states losing a pen and sheet

The facility will also replace the stolen pen once Youth A

• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment

A states other youth don’t have consequences like Youth A
does. Youth A also states youth exhibit similar behaviors
such as cursing, threatening, and talking about women but
don’t receive assignments. The response by Supervisor 2
states that staff do their best and don’t aways catch a youth
“in the act” but when staff are aware they take the

• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 2/3/24 from Youth A. Youth A
states staff disrespect Youth A and when Youth A told
another youth who told staff what Youth A reported, Youth
A received a disrespect assignment. Youth A also states
wanting justice for this action. Supervisor 2’s response was
that she spoke with Youth A and Youth A is presenting as
being an equal to staff. She informed Youth A that part of
12

the program is accepting assignments as issued and
watching how Youth A responds to staff.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 3/14/24 from Youth A. Youth
A states getting into an argument with staff and raising
Youth A’s voice before leaving the area. Youth A also
states staff accuse Youth A of trying to get staff in trouble.
Supervisor 2 responded to the grievance by documenting
how she processed the issues with Youth A. She noted
Youth A did well in processing and was able to identify
ways to change Youth A’s problematic behaviors. Youth A
also discussed ways to deal with Youth A’s feelings to
prevent negative interactions with others in the future.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 3/15/24 from Youth A. Youth
A stated Staff 1 told Youth B that Youth A is the worst youth
in the program and would bring everyone else down.
Supervisor 2 documented speaking to Staff 1 and Youth A..
She documented Youth A will avoid negative interactions
with Staff 1 in the future.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 3/15/24 from Youth A. Youth
A states Staff 1 broke Youth A’s boundaries after Youth A
told Staff 1 multiple times (no mention about what
happened that boundaries were broken) not to. Youth A
also reported Staff 1 did not give Youth D a consequence
when Youth D threatened Youth A. Supervisor 2
documented speaking to Staff 1, Youth A and Youth D and
focused on how Youth A can avoid conflict with Staff 1 in
the future.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 3/15/24 from Youth A. Youth
A states receiving an assignment for negative behaviors.
Supervisor 2 responded by documenting speaking with
Youth A about different ways to channel and own Youth A’s
behaviors. It is also documented they discussed ways
Youth A can limit negative interactions with staff.
• Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment
Program Grievance dated 4/12/25 and signed by Youth
A. Youth A documents a belief that he is not being
13

concerned about because his group work is not being
checked. Youth A also reports his culture is being violated
and his primary therapist doesn’t have time for him. Youth
A ends the statement by reporting he wants positive
change and to no longer feels like he amounts to nothing.
Administrator’s response: Youth A is thanked for writing the
grievance and notes telling Youth A’s that group work is not
checked right away so youth can absorb the material and
state to use it. The process does not allow for the work to
be rushed through but designed to give the youth a chance
to review older material so it can be put into use. It is also
documented that Youth A’s therapist is not at his beck and
call but have a caseload which spreads their time between
multiple responsibilities.
Bethany Christian Services Residential Treatment Program
Policies & Procedures 005-Suspected Staff Misconduct dated
2/25/20. This document outlines that all youth receiving care in the
residential treatment program will be treated in a humane,
dignified manner. It also outlines that staff are to respect the
emotional, physical, and mental boundaries of youth at all times.
The rest of this document outlines the procedure to be followed
when a staff member may be perceived as engaging in
